title: Delaying the Progression of Driving Impairment in Individuals With Mild Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: The purpose of the study is to determine whether memantine delays the progression of driving impairment in patients with mild Alzheimer's Disease (AD).
description_detailed:
It is well known, and of great concern to both patients and families, that individuals with Alzheimer's disease (AD) eventually become driving impaired. Drivers with dementia are estimated to be 2-8 times more likely to be involved in an automobile crash as unimpaired peers. Approximately half of individuals with mild AD have the skills needed to drive safely. Formal driver evaluation may be necessary to make this distinction. Some reviews in the literature have suggested that individuals identified as high risk, such as those with AD, be advised by their physicians to cease driving altogether. Other studies suggest that these individuals may continue to drive for up to 4 years following diagnosis. Memantine may be effective in delaying the progression of driving impairment in individuals with mild AD. If the investigators can demonstrate a significant delay in the decline in the driving ability, this could extend their driving time and therefore be of immense benefit to patients and their caregivers.

Comparison(s): Subjects treated with memantine over a period of 12 months, compared to subjects on placebo.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: Prior to randomization, subjects completed a screening visit to discuss/sign informed consent and determine study eligibility. Of the 60 subjects screened, 17 were excluded due to not passing the screening visit driving test, scoring out of the inclusion criteria range on screening visit assessments or meeting an exclusion criteria.
participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: Recruitment dates July 2007 - September 2011 Newspaper print ads, physician referral, subject referral, press releases

outcomeMeasures.title: The Primary Outcome Measure is the Number of Subjects in Each Group Who Are Able to Pass the DriveABLE On-Road Test at Month 12 (Endpoint).
outcomeMeasures.description: The DriveABLE On-Road Test utilizes a standardized road course and standardized scoring procedures designed to identify driving errors indicative of decline in competence scores. This road test takes approximately 30-45 minutes and covers a distance of approximately 9 miles.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: One subject in the placebo group could not complete the driving test at 12 months due to his vision being below the legal limit to drive.

outcomeMeasures.title: Fuld Object Memory Evaluation
outcomeMeasures.description:
Ten common objects in a bag were presented to determine whether the subject could identify objects by touch. The subject was not told that memory of this event would be tested. The subject names each object and then pulls it out of the bag to see if he is correct. After distracting the subject, by asking the patient to say words rapidly from a single category (rapid verbal retrieval), the subject is asked to recall the objects from the bag. The subject was then offered two more chances to learn and recall them (store and retrieve) by reminding the subject of omitted items after each recall, with rapid verbal retrieval preventing rehearsal before each recall opportunity.

Retrieval scores were summed over the three trials with the range of possible scores being 0-30. Lower scores indicate more severe impairment.

outcomeMeasures.title: Rey Complex Figure Test
outcomeMeasures.description: This is a measure of visual-spatial and constructional ability as well as higher order cognitive processes including planning, organizing, and problem solving. Subjects are asked to copy a complicated drawing. 18 elements are scored from 0-2 depending on accuracy/distortion and location of the reproduction. The maximum score is 36 points. Lower scores indicate more severe impairment

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: Placebo: One tablet placebo morning and evening (BID) for 12 months

groups.title: Memantine
groups.description: Memantine: One tablet memantine (Namenda)10mg morning and evening (BID) for 12 months

outcomeMeasures.title: Trail Making Test - Part A
outcomeMeasures.description: A simple test of visual tracking. The score is the time in seconds required to complete. Higher scores indicate lower functioning.

outcomeMeasures.title: Trail Making Test - Part B
outcomeMeasures.description: This tests cognitive flexibility and set-shifting. It is considered to be a test of executive functioning and has been shown to correlate with on-road driving ability. The score is the time in seconds required to complete each part. Higher scores indicate decreased functioning.

outcomeMeasures.title: Mini Mental Status Exam
outcomeMeasures.description: Scores range from 0-30 with lower scores indicating decreased functioning.

outcomeMeasures.title: Useful Field of View
outcomeMeasures.description: The Useful Field of View is a computer-administered test that measures higher order processing skills such as divided attention and visual processing speed. Scores can be predictive of ability to perform many everyday activities, such as driving a vehicle. Speed of visual processing is measured as the examinee identifies a target, but must also localize a simultaneously presented target displayed in the periphery of the computer monitor. Scores range from 1 to 4 with 1 being no impairment, 2= mild, 3= moderate and 4=serious impairment.

outcomeMeasures.title: Motor Free Visual Perception Test - Visual Closure Subtest
outcomeMeasures.description: This is an 11 item multiple choice test of visual perception. Scores range from 0-11. This test measures visual perception deficits separate from motor skill abilities. Higher scores indicate more severe impairment.

outcomeMeasures.title: Cognitive Dementia Rating Scale
outcomeMeasures.description: This scale is used to stage severity of dementia. Scores are on a five-point scale in which 0 indicates no cognitive impairment, .5 = very mild dementia,1 = mild, 2 = moderate and 3= severe.

outcomeMeasures.title: Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale - Cognitive Subscale (ADAS-Cog)
outcomeMeasures.description: The ADAS-Cog is a performance based test that measures specific cognitive and behavioral dysfunctions in patients with Alzheimer's disease. The cognitive subscale comprises 11 items which measure word recall (0-10), ability to follow single and multi-step commands (0-5), constructional praxis (0-5), ideational praxis (0-5), naming objects(0-5), word recognition (0-12), orientation (0-8), comprehension of spoken language (0-5), word finding difficulty(0-5) and ability to remember test instructions (0-5). 0 = no impairment with higher scores indicating more severe impairment.

seriousEvents.organSystem: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)
Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

otherEvents.organSystem: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

pointOfContact.title: Peter Holland, MD
pointOfContact.organization: Charles E. Schmidt College of Medicine, Florida Atlantic University

explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests memantine to delay progression of driving impairment in mild Alzheimer’s disease. Memantine is a small‑molecule, uncompetitive NMDA (N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate) receptor antagonist used to treat cognitive symptoms of Alzheimer’s disease rather than a biologic that targets core AD pathology (amyloid or tau). citeturn0search0turn0search1

Act: Key extracted details — Drug: memantine (small‑molecule NMDA receptor antagonist); Intended effect in this trial: slow decline in functional/cognitive ability related to driving (symptomatic/cognitive benefit). Evidence on memantine mechanism and clinical role: StatPearls (mechanism and use in AD), Alzforum (drug class and symptomatic role), and PubMed reviews summarizing memantine as an NMDA antagonist used for symptomatic treatment in moderate–severe AD. citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search3

Reflect: Classification rationale — memantine is not a biologic (so not 'disease‑targeted biologic') and does not specifically target amyloid or tau pathology (so not 'disease‑targeted small molecule' by the definitions provided). Its primary approved/typical use is to ameliorate cognitive and functional symptoms of AD via glutamatergic modulation, so the best fit is 'cognitive enhancer.' The trial’s goal (delay driving impairment) aligns with symptomatic/cognitive/functional preservation rather than a pathology‑modifying mechanism. No placebo or comparator was specified in the short description. citeturn0search0turn0search9
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial tests memantine, a small‑molecule uncompetitive NMDA (N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate) receptor antagonist, to slow functional/cognitive decline (driving impairment) in mild AD. This indicates the intervention is acting on glutamatergic neurotransmission (a neurotransmitter receptor) and is intended as a symptomatic/cognitive enhancer rather than a direct anti‑amyloid or anti‑tau disease‑modifying agent. citeturn0search2turn0search3turn0search7

Act: Extracted details — Drug: memantine; Mechanism: uncompetitive/low‑affinity NMDA receptor antagonist (blocks/pathologically overactive glutamatergic signaling); Clinical role in AD: symptomatic cognitive/functional treatment (approved for moderate‑to‑severe AD and used to ameliorate cognitive symptoms). Based on these specifics, the most appropriate CADRO category is D) Neurotransmitter Receptors. citeturn0search2turn0search1turn0search7

Reflect: Confirmation — Memantine targets NMDA glutamate receptors (neurotransmitter receptors) and is used to produce symptomatic cognitive benefit rather than to remove amyloid or tau or directly modify those proteopathic pathways; therefore the classification D) Neurotransmitter Receptors is the best fit. This is not multi‑target disease modification nor a diagnostic/non‑therapeutic trial, so 'D' is specific and appropriate. citeturn0search6turn0search3

Web search results (sources used): 1) StatPearls / NCBI Bookshelf — Memantine: mechanism as an uncompetitive/low‑affinity NMDA receptor antagonist and clinical use in AD. citeturn0search2 2) PubMed review / preclinical evidence — memantine as an NMDA antagonist with symptomatological and neuroprotective rationale in AD. citeturn0search3 3) Alzforum summary/webinar — pharmacology and clinical trial evidence supporting memantine's symptomatic efficacy in AD. citeturn0search7
